Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Changes in Brain Morphology Induced by Repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Simulation Treatment for Major Depression Disorder

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the summer of 2010 I had the opportunity to conduct research in Dr. Jen-Chun Hsieh’s lab at Taipei Veterans General Hospital. In Dr. Hsieh’s lab I had learned various magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) brain image analysis techniques. My primary training was in voxel based morphometry (VBM) and diffusion tensor imaging (DTI). VBM is used primarily to assess gray matter and DTI to assess white matter volume of the brain.

The project I worked on focused on the relationship between changes in brain structure and Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS). Differences between IBS patients and normal control subjects without IBS were determined with VBM analysis on MRI images taken from both groups of people. It is hypothesized that continuous and long term pain and discomfort associated with IBS can lead to changes in brain morphology. Understanding these changes in IBS patients and regular patients will lead to better understanding of IBS and brain function in general. Currently the exact causes of IBS are unknown. At the end of my summer research VBM analysis of IBS and control subjects identified several differences in brain morphology in the IBS and control patient groups. Most notably the volume in the amygdale, anterior cingulate cortex, and cingulate gyrus increased in volume while volume in the posterior lobe of the cerebellum for IBS subjects decreased. The anterior cingulate cortex,cingulate gyrus, and amygdala are regions associated with emotion and pain. This illustrates the neurological effect IBS can have on neuroanatomy and demonstrates that chronic pain is associated with neural restructuring. It also provides an anatomical foundation to explore potential mechanisms that explain the effect of stress and other emotional triggers in inducing IBS symptoms. Using this knowledge we hope to further illuminate the association of different brain areas with their higher level function.

The summer I spent in Dr. Hsieh’s lab was a valuable professional experience; I had the opportunity to conduct research in a field complimentary to my PhD work and establish research contacts in Taiwan (both in Dr. Hsieh’s lab and with other institutions like ITRI). My research in the United States involves understanding human 3D visual perception. Gaining hands-on experience in a clinical imaging lab (to better understand how we can visualize medical images in stereo 3D) and thinking about neuroscience from an anatomical perspective (we use psychophysics techniques that analyze the brain from a systems level) will help me immensely in future research career.
